perturbation.explanation: Moving the governing law clause to the section describing duties obscures its importance and makes it less likely to be noticed and understood. It now appears to be part of Bravatek's duties rather than a fundamental aspect of the contract.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas law requires choice of law provisions to be conspicuous to ensure enforceability. By burying the governing law clause within a section detailing Bravatek's duties, it becomes less conspicuous and could be argued as not fairly presented to both parties, potentially undermining its enforceability.

perturbation.original_text: 4) Compensation When custom Products are designed, developed and to be delivered to Bravatek-identified perspective clients, the parties shall agree to a proposed sales price for use during the project in writing prior to the commencement of each project. 2 For any Product or Solution sold to any perspective clients introduced by Bravatek registered with COMPANY via email to COMPANY's CEO and delivered through Bravatek or a COMPANY-designated distribution affiliate(s) or sales channel(s), Bravatek will receive a lead-finder fee, to be mutually discussed and finally decided by COMPANY at the range of minimum of 10% to maximum of 20% of project revenue, with an exact fee to be depending upon the overall project sales margin and cost of development and delivery of each project, payable NET 30 days after each client payment on delivered products received at COMPANY's bank account.

11) Modifications
No changes or modifications of this Agreement or any of its terms shall be deemed effective unless in writing and executed by the parties hereto. 4) Compensation When custom Products are designed, developed and to be delivered to Bravatek-identified perspective clients, the parties shall agree to a proposed sales price for use during the project in writing prior to the commencement of each project. 2 For any Product or Solution sold to any perspective clients introduced by Bravatek registered with COMPANY via email to COMPANY's CEO and delivered through Bravatek or a COMPANY-designated distribution affiliate(s) or sales channel(s), Bravatek will receive a lead-finder fee, to be mutually discussed and finally decided by COMPANY at the range of minimum of 10% to maximum of 20% of project revenue, with an exact fee to be depending upon the overall project sales margin and cost of development and delivery of each project, payable NET 30 days after each client payment on delivered products received at COMPANY's bank account.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the compensation clause under the modifications clause makes it harder to locate and could be argued as obscuring the intended payment terms. The fee structure being placed under 'modifications' could allow a party to argue that the compensation can be modified at any time.
perturbation.law_explanation: This relocation introduces uncertainty regarding the fixed or modifiable nature of the compensation terms. In Texas, the absence of a specified price in a contract of sale usually indicates that the price is a reasonable price at the time of delivery. However, if the contract states that the price can be altered as per modification clauses, that could be challenged.

perturbation.explanation: Moving the indemnification clause after the confidentiality clause disrupts the logical flow of the contract. Indemnification clauses are crucial for risk allocation. Hiding this clause inside the confidential information terms would cause one party to assume the other party had additional confidential information to hide.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law Principles, specifically concerning the enforceability of contract terms due to lack of conspicuousness.
perturbation.law_explanation: Moving the indemnification clause makes it less conspicuous and could lead to arguments that it was not reasonably brought to the attention of the other party. The enforceability of a contract term requires that the term is understandable and it has been fairly brought to the attention of the contracting party. Burying it inside the confidential information would fail to do so.
